title: Emotional Regulation Together
description: Learn how you help each other manage big emotions.

questions.text: When I'm emotionally overwhelmed, what helps most?

therapeutic.rationale: Overwhelm support needs reveal co-regulation patterns. Presence-needers co-regulate through proximity; space-needers self-regulate first; talk-throughers process externally; physical-comfort seekers regulate through touch. Providing the right support during overwhelm can dramatically shift emotional states.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different overwhelm support needs require flexibility. The space-needer feels smothered by presence pursuit; the presence-needer feels abandoned by space-giving. Ask before acting.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared overwhelm support makes helping intuitive. You know what helps because it's what would help you.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: When emotionally overwhelmed, what actually helps? What makes it worse? Does your partner know?

questions.text: How do I typically calm down after a strong emotion?
choices: Connection with you helps me settle
Talking it out until I feel resolved

therapeutic.rationale: Calming-down strategies reveal regulation capacity. Connection-calmers co-regulate through relationship; alone-processors self-regulate; movement-users regulate through body; talk-outers process externally. Knowing your partner's regulation strategy helps you support rather than disrupt their process.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different calming strategies need respect. The connection-calmer may pursue the alone-processor, disrupting their regulation. Honor your partner's process even when different from yours.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared calming strategies can be done together. Two talk-outers will process together; two alone-processors will respect each other's space.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do you calm down after strong emotions? Does your current approach work well? What would improve your emotional regulation?

questions.text: What emotional support do I offer you naturally?
choices: I try to fix or solve problems

therapeutic.rationale: Natural support style reflects your attachment strengths. Present-listeners offer safety; fixers offer practical help; physical-comforters offer co-regulation; space-givers offer autonomy. Your natural style may or may not match what your partner needs.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different natural supports mean adapting matters. Your fixing may frustrate a listening-needer; your space-giving may feel cold to a presence-needer. Offer what they need, not what you naturally give.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared support styles mean you'll offer what helps. You naturally provide what would help you, which happens to help your partner too.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What emotional support do you naturally offer? Does it match what your partner needs? How could you adapt?

questions.text: When we're both stressed, what happens between us?
choices: We support each other and grow closer
We tend to clash or conflict
One of us holds it together for both

therapeutic.rationale: Mutual stress patterns reveal relationship resilience. Closer-growers have secure stress response; clashers have competing attachment needs; space-givers may avoid; one-holds patterns risk imbalance. How you handle simultaneous stress determines whether hard times strengthen or strain you.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different mutual stress responses need awareness. If one always holds it together, burnout follows. If you clash, recognize it's two triggered nervous systems, not two opponents.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared mutual stress response is your pattern. Know it, and consciously create what you want rather than defaulting.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: When you're both stressed, what happens? Is this pattern serving you? What would healthier mutual stress look like?

questions.text: How can you help me feel emotionally regulated?
choices: Stay calm even when I'm not
Validate that my feelings make sense
Hold me or be physically close

therapeutic.rationale: Regulation help preferences reveal what calms your nervous system. Calm-staying provides co-regulation; validation confirms you're not crazy; time-giving respects your process; physical closeness offers safety. Your partner is telling you exactly how to help them regulate.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different regulation help needs guide your response. The time-needer may feel pressured by physical closeness. Provide what your partner needs.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared regulation help makes support intuitive. You know what helps because it's what would help you.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What helps you feel emotionally regulated? Does your partner do these things? Have you asked clearly for what helps?
